title: MP13-03 IMPACT OF SYNCHRONOUS BLADDER CANCER ON RECURRENCE-FREE SURVIVAL AFTER SURGICAL TREATMENT FOR PRIMARY URETHRAL CANCER: RESULTS FROM THE INTERNATIONAL COLLABORATION ON PRIMARY URETHRAL CARCINOMA (ICPUC)

Thalmann More articles by this author , and Arnulf StenzlArnulf Stenzl More articles by this author View All Author Informationhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.juro.2014.02.672AboutPDF ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack CitationsPermissionsReprints ShareFacebookTwitterLinked InEmail INTRODUCTION AND OBJECTIVES Primary urethral cancer is a rare urogenital malignancy with an annual incidence of 1.1/1.000.000 in Europe. It may clinically occur together with synchronous bladder cancer (BCa). The present study aimed to evaluate the impact of synchronous bladder cancer on the risk of local and/or distant failure in patients undergoing surgery for primary treatment of urethral cancer. METHODS Of 171 patients (116 men, 55 women), who were diagnosed with primary urethral cancer between 1993 and 2012 in ten tertiary international academic centers, 107 (63%) underwent surgery for primary treatment. Kaplan-Meier analysis with log-rank testing was used to investigate the impact of synchronous BCa on recurrence-free survival (RFS). A multivariable model was constructed to evaluate independent risk factors for recurrence. Based on regression estimates of significant parameters in multivariable analysis a novel weighted scoring model was developed to predict recurrence after surgery. The median follow-up was 20 months (mean: 32 months; IQR: 4-48). RESULTS Median age at surgery was 67 years (IQR: 53-74). Of the 107 patients, transurethral tumor resection was conducted in 31 (29%), total or partial urethrectomy in 36 (34%) and cystoprostatectomy with urethrectomy in 40 patients (37%). Synchronous and metachronous BCa was diagnosed in 19 (18%) and 3 (3%) patients, respectively, while a prior history of BCa was present in 24 patients (22%). The 5-year RFS in patients with synchronous vs. no BCa/non-synchronous BCa was 30.5 and 47.9%, respectively. In multivariable analysis, adjusted for age, gender and tumor location (proximal vs. distal), inferior RFS was associated with advanced pathological tumor stage (≥pT3; p=0.004; score 2 vs. 0), positive clinical nodal stage (cN+; p=0.003, score 3 vs. 0) and synchronous BCa (p=0.016, score 2 vs. 0). The 5-year RFS in patients with a score 0 (low-risk), 2 (intermediate risk) and 3-7 (high-risk) was 67.8%, 43.1% and 0%, respectively (p<0.001). Consideration of synchronous BCa in the final model increased its predictive accuracy by 1.4% with a concordance index of 0.653 (p=0.047). CONCLUSIONS Synchronous BCa is an independent predictor for inferior RFS in patients after surgical treatment for primary urethral cancer. After external validation, this straightforward prognostic risk model may serve for tailored monitoring and selection of appropriate patients for adjuvant trials. © 2014FiguresReferencesRelatedDetails Volume 191Issue 4SApril 2014Page: e176-e177 Peer Review Report Advertisement Copyright & Permissions© 2014MetricsAuthor Information Georgios Gakis More articles by this author Jason A.
